documentType: FBI Electronic Communication / Property Transfer Record
summary: This document is a series of FBI electronic communications and a property receipt regarding the closure and transfer of case files for investigation 72-MM-113327, involving Alfredo Rodriguez. It details the administrative closure of the case after Rodriguez's sentencing, the return of his property, and the eventual transfer of extensive case files (including items like Epstein's phone book, travel documents, and non-prosecution agreements) to the Washington Field Office in 2025.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.context: The subject of FBI investigation 72-MM-113327. The case was closed after he was sentenced and all prosecutorial matters were resolved. Property was returned to him in 2013.

events.title: Full Investigation Initiated
events.description: The FBI's full investigation (72-MM-113327) into Alfredo Rodriguez was initiated.

events.title: Case Closure Requested
events.description: An FBI electronic communication requested the closure of case 72-MM-113327 because the defendant (Alfredo Rodriguez) had been sentenced and all prosecutorial matters resolved.

events.title: Property Returned to Rodriguez
events.description: The FBI documented the return of property to Alfredo Rodriguez via an FD-597 receipt.

events.title: Case Files Transferred to Washington
events.description: Extensive case files from investigation 72-MM-113327 were shipped via FedEx from Riviera Beach, FL, to the Washington Field Office Evidence room.

locations: 1501 ECKINGTON PLACE NORTHEAST, WASHINGTON, DC (FedEx pickup location)
keyFacts: The FBI investigation (72-MM-113327) into Alfredo Rodriguez was closed in December 2012 after he was sentenced and all prosecutorial matters were resolved.
In March 2025, a large volume of case files from this investigation was physically transferred to the FBI's Washington Field Office, indicating ongoing relevance or review.
The transferred files contained materials directly linking to Jeffrey Epstein, including multiple folders labeled 'Epstein phone book Docs' and one labeled 'Rodriguez & Epstein'.
Other notable names found in the file inventory include Steven Hoffenberg, Leslie Wexner, and a 'Non-Prosecution agreement', suggesting the investigation's scope touched on broader networks.
The files included a wide array of evidence types: phone records, subpoena returns, plea agreements, consent to search forms, photos, court documents, and email correspondence.
